head.title: A Gadfly, but One With a Difference

hedline.hl1: A Gadfly, but One With a Difference

abstract.p: Andre Piazza, a former R & B Falcon employee and a familiar gadlfy at company meetings, disrupts annual meeting by brandishing hand grenade and pulling pin when asked to hold his questions until later; a company official wrestles grenade away from Piazza; the grenade turns out to be a harmless dummy, but Piazza is arrested on misdemeanor charge of making a terrorist threat (M)

block.p: It's a familiar problem for many corporate executives: that one shareholder who turns up at the annual meeting with a loud voice and a scowl and not much patience for the company line.
Few executives, however, may face the disruption that greeted Paul Lloyd, chairman of R & B Falcon, an oil-drilling contractor, just as its annual meeting was getting under way in Houston last week.
It's a familiar problem for many corporate executives: that one shareholder who turns up at the annual meeting with a loud voice and a scowl and not much patience for the company line.
Few executives, however, may face the disruption that greeted Paul Lloyd, chairman of R & B Falcon, an oil-drilling contractor, just as its annual meeting was getting under way in Houston last week.

Unwilling to hold his questions until later, Andre Piazza, 72, a former employee and familiar face at company meetings, pulled what looked like a hand grenade out of his bag and removed the safety pin, the Houston police said.

As the audience dived for the exits, a company official managed to get hold of the grenade, and Mr. Piazza was arrested. It turned out to be a harmless dummy, so the police charged Mr. Piazza with making a terrorist threat, a misdemeanor. The meeting resumed after 45 minutes.
